text: This is a recurring topic "_Agreed. Docs of major projects are still incomplete or non-existent, there's a lot of projects that have been nigh abandoned (cough naive bayes cough), and ..."_   perhaps we should take it more seriously.

text: The problem here is definitely not that people aren't aware of this problem, but writing good docs is really hard and package maintainers are usually already busy as-is. Julia does participate in GSoD and there are more and more packages putting lots of effort into documentation, but it's not something that will happen overnight.

elements.text: The problem here is definitely not that people aren't aware of this problem, but writing good docs is really hard and package maintainers are usually already busy as-is. Julia does participate in GSoD and there are more and more packages putting lots of effort into documentation, but it's not something that will happen overnight.

text: <@UM30MT6RF> yes, I understand that package developers are usually busy as it is. However, we could have a documentathon or something like that. At least make examples on the julialang documentation and the most used packages.

elements.text: yes, I understand that package developers are usually busy as it is. However, we could have a documentathon or something like that. At least make examples on the julialang documentation and the most used packages.

text:
> The problem here is definitely not that people aren't aware of this problem, but writing good docs is really hard and package maintainers are usually already busy as-is.
I think it's a community culture thing. As a community, Julia values code more than docs. That's not an inherently good or bad thing (and I think focusing on code makes sense when you're young and exploring and growing).

But Python developers and Java developers (etc.) also only have 24 hours in the day. It's just that they (or at least, some circles) do put a premium on documentation that (most of) the Julia community does not. If you make a contribution to pandas that's not well documented, it will get rejected, no matter how clean the code is because they place a premium on documentation.

elements.text: The problem here is definitely not that people aren't aware of this problem, but writing good docs is really hard and package maintainers are usually already busy as-is.

I think it's a community culture thing. As a community, Julia values code more than docs. That's not an inherently good or bad thing (and I think focusing on code makes sense when you're young and exploring and growing).

But Python developers and Java developers (etc.) also only have 24 hours in the day. It's just that they (or at least, some circles) do put a premium on documentation that (most of) the Julia community does not. If you make a contribution to pandas that's not well documented, it will get rejected, no matter how clean the code is because they place a premium on documentation.

text: It has felt like a lot of things I have had to kind of just learn on the go, so whenever people ask me for resources on "How do I learn Julia as an R user" its hard to say much besides listing some similar packages and diving right in

elements.text: It has felt like a lot of things I have had to kind of just learn on the go, so whenever people ask me for resources on "How do I learn Julia as an R user" its hard to say much besides listing some similar packages and diving right in

text:
TL;DR; We lack _digested_ documentation that is newbie friendly.

That's the usual feedback that I get from people: _"I can't find any answers on how to do X in Stack Overflow"_, _"the official documentation is written by experts for experts"_ and _"I can't find any documentation of PackageA so I can't use it"._ Personally I have found that many packages refer to external references for their package so, you need to learn how to use the external package (usually for another programming language or another context like an RFC) and _then_ how to map this knowledge to the Julia package. This creates cognitive friction from people that want to (casually) start using Julia, but don't have the required knowledge to use the packages.  Let's face it, people like documentation with examples that they can copy/paste and make work now and think about it later.

how to map this knowledge to the Julia package. This creates cognitive friction from people that want to (casually) start using Julia, but don't have the required knowledge to use the packages.  Let's face it, people like documentation with examples that they can copy/paste and make work now and think about it later.

text: An additional problem I’ve frequently encountered is figuring out which library to use for a problem. This could be figuring out which plotting or data manipulation package to use. In that case I may need to learn on some level two or three before deciding on the one, and learning this others was just overhead.

text: I often would try Google first, and I could find an answer that is a blog post written in 2017 but there’s no date in the post. There’s also no knowing if the person who wrote it knows what he/she is talking about.

text: This is slightly off julia topic, but I googled several times about how to use google cloud, and the blog posts I found usually spent 70% of text in exlaining the background, and then a bit of actual answer but not too well that either. In the end google’s official docs are way superior, like this whole section on the compute engine to just give an example. <https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/quickstarts|https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/quickstarts>

text: in any language, you need time to be familiar with it. once you reach a certain limit of hours, everything becomes easy. the julia documentation is quiet good but you need to read it several times to digest it. also, reading julia code in several packages help a lot. julia is meant to be explored by the fact that its packages are written in julia instead of another language. i consider reading those packages very much helpful plus the julia documentation.

text: there is no shortcut. first, you must be really interested to know the language. read the docs and find out its features and the way it does things. read the doc again and practice implementing things. ladder, rinse, repeat until that muscle memory develop julia-muscles.

text: the official julia documentation is quiet complete. no effort to stitch there. for packages, it’s not sponsored by companies but still i find a lot of packages quiet stable. if you are coming from another language like python, it takes time to shake that memory muscles and change python to julia workflow of thinking. people are too pampered with easy stuffs of python.  if you developed in assembly or C++ before where you have to mine the reference manuals, julia is a walk in the park.

text: <@U6SHSF4R0> reading these source code is something that I can do, but not something I prefer. I recently found a gap in the Julia documentation that took me a couple of hours to figure out because the documentation was incomplete, google didn't help, helpdesk kind of helped which pointed to the general direction, then sort of figure out by trial and error and reading the (C language) source code. I would have rather spent that time working with my problem rather than figuring out what was missing in the documentation.

text: Well, that's the kind of work that I would expect from Julia Computing and I'd willing to pay for _premium_ documentation if that saves me some time. Also, as Travis said, the community doesn't seem to put much value on documentation whereas other projects like Rust that are about as old as Julia have much better documentation.

text: you got that wrong, I am a Julian ... I am greedy ... I want my cake and eat it too, I want the best language with the best documentation. If you think that the documentation is fine, great for you! However, I disagree with you, I think that it's adequate but could be greatly improved and I think that _we_ should do something about it (perhaps you don't think is necessary, but I am pretty sure that others agree with me). I can contribute my share, but this is a group effort.  However, my time is also valuable and I'd be willing to pay for some extra from Julia Computing if that helps me save some time.
